captions.text:
So, I'm going to start by walking you
into a scene in a movie

and then I want you all
to tell me what happens next.

Christmas Eve. Beautiful night. 
Light snowfall.

Young family of four in the car,
on the way to grandma's house for dinner.
They're listening to the radio station,

the one that starts playing the
Christmas music like right at Halloween.

"Jingle Bells" comes on. 
The kids in the back seat go crazy.
Everyone breaks into song.

The camera pans in on the faces
of the kids, the mom, dad...
What happens next?
Car crash.
Sixty percent of people say "car crash".
Sixty percent.

Another 10 to 15 percent have
equally fatalistic answers,
but more creative.
(Laughter)
I have:
"The camera cuts to the oncologist,

who is looking at the bad news that he's
going to share the day after Christmas."

I have:
"They get to grandmother's house,

everyone is dead,
a serial killer is on the loose."
(Laughter)

And I had one dude
who worked in a shark attack.
(Laugher)
I did.
What's interesting to me about this

and I--it's an indictment, a little bit,
of the media, which I wouldn't so much

care about, except that
I'm a vulnerability researcher,

and I've spent the last 10 years studying
vulnerability, and I cannot tell you

how many hundreds and hundreds of stories
that I've collected from people

who, that is their response, not just
to media, but in their real lives.

How many parents I've interviewed
who will say:

"...and I'm looking at my children, 
and they're sleeping, and I'm on this
--just right at the verge of bliss....

And I picture
something horrible happening."

Do you know this?
Yes.

I get the promotion, and
I get to fly up to headquarters,

you know, to find out about my new job. 
And what's going to happen?
Plane crashes.

The fatalistic response is not universal.
We're not all like that.

But it is a symptom of an issue
that is both universal and, I believe,
profoundly dangerous.

And that is: We are losing
our tolerance for vulnerability.
And in our culture, we--

what do we think
is synonymous with vulnerability?
Weakness.

You are an excellent audience.
(Laughter)
It's almost as if I trained you.
It's perfect.
Weakness.

And I am going to talk about
how that's not the case, tonight.
Vulnerability is absolutely at the core
of fear, and anxiety, and shame,

and very difficult emotions 
that we all experience.

But vulnerability is also
the birthplace of joy,

of love, of belonging,
of creativity, of faith.

And so it becomes very problematic
when, as a culture,
we lose our capacity to be vulnerable.

So, this kind of fatalistic car crash
is a symptom.
I refer to it as "foreboding joy".
One of the symptoms

that we're losing our capacity
for vulnerability is that joy
actually becomes foreboding.

Something good happens,
or we're looking at someone we love,

or we're thinking about
something we care about,

and then we become compelled 
to beat vulnerability to the punch.

Other symptoms:
Disappointment as a lifestyle.

It is much easier to live disappointed 
than it is to feel disappointment.

And so, this is the person
in the afterschool movie that's:

"I don't want to play your stupid game
because it's dumb and boring

and because really
maybe nobody will ask me."

We sidestep getting excited
about something,

because we're not sure
it's actually going to happen.

Low-grade disconnection is another
symptom of vulnerability avoidance.

We go through the motions.
It's like low-grade fever:

It may not kill us,
but it keeps us pretty miserable.

Perfection is one of the
--I call it "the 200-pound shield":

"How could anything go wrong
if my life looks like an ad?"

"I am going to perform, and please, 
and make sure everything's perfect."

And perfectionism has nothing to do with
striving for excellence and healthy--
it's nothing to do with healthy striving.

People who I interview
who are absolutely accomplished,

and people who strive for excellence
are the biggest negotiators

and compromisers
that I've ever interviewed.
Perfection is a tool to protect ourselves.
Extremism.
There is a very simple equation:
Faith
minus vulnerability
equals extremism.

Faith is the vulnerability that flows 
between the shores of certainty.

Faith without vulnerability
--spirituality is inherently vulnerable.

It is believing in things 
we don't understand or really can't see.

And last, I believe the most universal way
that we are dealing with

an intolerance for vulnerability
in our culture, is that we numb.
And I'll talk about this in a minute.

Let's go to a bigger question,
and that is:

What is driving this intolerance
for vulnerability in us?
And I believe the answer is scarcity.

We live in a culture that tells us
that there is never enough.

That we are not enough,
that we are not good enough,
that we are not safe enough,

that we can never be certain enough, 
that we are not perfect enough

and maybe the one
that we really don't talk about,

that I think is perhaps
the most dangerous,
is that we are not extraordinary enough.
In this world, somehow, an ordinary life

has become synonymous
with a meaningless life.

And so often we are missing
what is truly important

because we're on the quest
for what is extraordinary.

Not understanding
that in our ordinary lives,
in the ordinary moments of our lives,
is really where we can find the most joy.

One of the things that happens,
I think, in our culture of scarcity

is that we are constantly collecting
images and messages and experiences

--I think it's unconscious--
I really don't think that we're aware

of how many messages
and images of scarcity
that we collect every day.

I want to tell a story about something
that happened about 6 months ago,
that I think really illustrates this.

So, I have to catch a flight
to go do a talk somewhere,

and my daughter--I have 5 year-old
and an 11 year-old--

my daughter's really struggling
with a school project
I am definitely in the scarcity mode:

"I shouldn't be going,
I'm not a good enough mom,

I need to...this is...
I can't balance all of this."

I have to go to my bank, which is inside
of a grocery store, which--

--I don't know if that happens here,
but in Texas,

all the banks have moved
inside the grocery stores--
(Laughter)

So, I walk up to the grocery store's
sliding glass...the sliding glass doors,

and there's a big Code Adam sticker,
which, if you don't know what that is,

it's an incredibly important program,
but it's a program that says:

"This store and its employees are trained
that when a child has gone missing

or nabbed, everything
in the store shuts down."
So I look at that and I think:
"Oh God. OK, just stay focused, Brené.

No one's going to nab
your kids while you're away."

I get my money, get back in the car,
get on the freeway toward the airport,

and I pass the AMBER Alert.
"Keep driving, Brené, keep driving."
About 2 miles past the AMBER Alert
there's a sign that tells me

that 39 people been killed
on that specific stretch of highway.
And [to] please wear my seat belt.
(Laughter)

Then I get to the airport, and of course,
I'm in line to security getting naked,

and I hear: "The threat code
has been moved to orange."

And then I go through
this thing that I'm like:

"Oh my God! Holy crap! 
Is that a movement? Is it always orange?"

I was like, I'm going to start writing
on my hand with a Sharpie:

"It's always orange. Ok. Orange is not
--it hasn't gone bad."
I'm like: "What is it?"

So I'm like, "Orange. Ok, it's orange.
I think it was orange yesterday.
(Laughter)

Maybe something's
happened and I was busy

reading the AMBER Alert,
then trying to find the license plate..."

So I get to my gate
and I sit down and they're like:

"Do not leave unattended baggage...,"
and I look down, and there's a bag.
(Laughter)

And I'm like: 
"Oh my God! Wait--it's a diaper bag."

And I know that mother is ten feet away,
chasing her kid, and I'm like,
"But I saw this on Law and Order."
(Laughter)

And I'm going to board that plane and then
the next thing you're going to hear is:

"Ching-ching!"
That Law and Order "ching": DU-duum!
And then we're going to blow up.

So I get on the plane,
and I'm really getting ready to start--

--I'm in kind of what you would call,
I would say, an anxiety attack.
So I'm having an anxiety attack,

and the guy--I'm flying in business class,
the guy comes in, he's sitting next to me,

he turned out to be
a supply chain manager consultant--

and so he looks over,
and he's like: "You OK?"
I'm like, "I'm good, yeah. What's up?"

And my phone rings
and my son's face pops up.

Well, he's 5, so that means
his school is calling.
"Hello?"

"Charlie's got a fever.
Can you come get him?"

Mmm hmm.
So I text my husband, I take care of it,

and the guy next to me says:
"Really, are you OK?"

By this time, the cabin doors are closed.
And I say:

"You know what, I'm good, but I'm having
that thing where I can't decide

[if] my gut is saying get off
the flight, something's going to happen

or I'm just freaking out, and I'm trying
to figure out how to do something

crazy enough to get off the flight,
but to not end up on the 'No Fly' list."
(Laughter)
And so, this--Yeah, I am SUPER blast to fly with.
(Laughter)
So then he said: "Let me get you a drink."
(Laughter)
I said, "You know, I don't drink."
And he goes: "Xanax?"

And I was like,
"No, I don't do Xanax either."
...which is a shame.

(Laughter)
But, I don't.

But then what I realize is,
it really makes me think about my work.
Because we numb vulnerability.

Now had he said:
"Chips and queso?"

That would have been
a completely different issue.
(Laughter)
Evidence of the numbing:
We are the most addicted;
we are the most medicated;

obese, and in-debt
adult cohort in human history.
We're numbing.

And this doesn't even include busyness. 
I didn't even put the "Busy" slide up.

You know, when they start having
"busy" recovery meetings,

you know, "busy" 12-step meetings, they'll
have to rent out football stadiums.
Because we just stay so busy

that the truth of our lives
can't catch up.
That's the plan.

And so, what are the consequences 
of numbing vulnerability?

What are the consequences of
trying to beat vulnerability to the punch?

Here is the consequence
to numbing that I've learned:

As a vulnerability researcher 
I spent the first 6 years of my research
studying shame, empathy, and courage;

and the last 4 years studying joy, 
authenticity, love, and belonging.

And one of the things that I learned
that was very startling for me personally
and everyone I've ever met,

is that you cannot
selectively numb emotion.

When we numb the dark emotion, 
when we numb vulnerability and fear,

and the shame of not being
good enough, we by default numb joy.

We cannot selectively
just numb the dark emotions.
We have interesting research around this.
We have research that shows us,

in addiction studies,
that an intensely positive experience

is as likely to trigger relapse 
as an intensely negative experience.

Let me tell you:
if vulnerability is a sharp edge,
there may be nothing sharper than joy.

To let yourself soften
into loving someone,
into caring about something passionately--
that's vulnerable.

So the question becomes: 
How do we embrace vulnerability?

And here's what I learned
from the research:
We practice gratitude.
We stop and be thankful for what we have.

I've interviewed a lot of people
who have been through

many horrific things,
from genocide to trauma,

and when you ask them
what they need, they will tell you:

"I don't need your pity,
I don't need your sympathy.

When you look at your children,
I need to know you're grateful.

I need to know
that you know what you have."

So to practice gratitude, to honor
what's ordinary about our lives,

because that is
what's truly extraordinary.

We can compete
with the images from the media,

from the news,
from the scary shows on TV,

with our own images of gratitude 
about what's ordinary in our lives:
The people we love; our kids; our family;
play; our community; and nature.

These are things that happen
every single day

that we're so busy
being afraid we're missing.

So that's, I think, the biggest thing,
is to be grateful for what we have,
to honor what's ordinary.

And last, I just want to say that--and I'm
a parent and I'm a vulnerable person, too,

but I really believe we want more
guarantees; we want to believe

we're not going to get hurt
and bad things are not going to happen
and they are.

But there is a guarantee
that no one talks about, and that is:

if we don't allow ourselves
to experience joy and love
we will definitely miss out

on filling our reservoir with what we need
when those hard things happen.

And so, I'll end on the note
that I'm grateful for your time tonight,

and I'm grateful to be here, and I hope
this is something that we can do together,

because I believe
[that] in vulnerability

we'll find what really gives
purpose and meaning to our lives.

Thank you.
(Applause)

comments.text:
I always cry when i share about my life in public. I thought it was wrong 
and being vulnerable is a weakness. You're the first speaker that accepts 
our own true self. Many portrayed themselves to be strong, but some are 
actually hurting inside, no one knows.People pretend, camouflage 
themselves, so not to be labelled as vulnerable. Thank you for the message 
that i can be myself not because i am weak, but i am strong and bold enough 
to admit to my true feelings which bring joys to me.﻿
comments.author: Pek Meng Meng

comments.text:
+Randy Zeitman The question wasn't for me, so I hope you don't mind my 2 
cents. I think the result is dependent on why we are sharing our pain and 
who we share it with. Brene Brown's book The Gift of Imperfection talks 
about sharing shame with appropriate compassionate friends, because telling 
the story of shame takes the power away from it. Shame festers and grows 
when it's kept secret. Sharing helped me, personally. Debilitating anxiety 
showed up last September, and I was ashamed of it. I didn't start to 
overcome it until I was willing to admit to those closest to me about what 
I was going through. When I tried to hide the anxiety, I was also denying 
to myself that it exists, and we can't overcome something that we're not 
willing to admit is real. The more willing I have been to admit to the 
anxiety in public, especially in front of strangers who I would rather have 
a good impression of me, the less power it has had over me.
comments.author: Nikki R. (The King's Table)

comments.text:
+Randy Zeitman It wasn't meant to make me feel better. By sharing my life, 
brings back to what has happened in the past. It wasn't easy to go through 
it but because of God's grace i am able to endure it. The tears were not of 
sorrow but more of tears of thankfulness and gratefulness. Christians do 
share about our testimony that is meant to glorify God's faithfulness. Is 
definitely not to highlight about my pain but to praise God for His 
goodness.

comments.text:
excellent TED talk from +Brene Brown This topic of vulnerability is still a 
topic most people see as a weakness, when in reality is a strength.  I hope

comments.text:
These inspirational talks unveil the cultural conspiracy of emotional 
dishonesty. Shame is the most damaging and toxic emotion - we all feel it, 
[except for psychopaths] yet all we are taught is how to hide, deny and 
avoid it. I am inspired to buy, read and share her books and to take these 
concepts into my work. Brene Brown does not just expose the unsafe defences 
we can sometimes hide behind, but also teaches how to build the resilience 
that can stop us allowing fear of failure to prevent us from doing our best 
work.﻿

comments.author: airan peleg

comments.text:
She doesn't "force" herself to be vulnerable at all - have you followed any 
of Brene's work? She allows herself to feel and experience vulnerability, 
which doesn't come naturally for her, or for many of us. Despite this, 
she's prepared to share stories of her own vulnerability with us in a 
public forum - vulnerability doesn't get much more authentic than that. 
That highway and airport story was all about scarcity, not feeling that 
she's enough, the internal conflict as to what she was supposed to be at 
the time - should she be on that flight? Or should she be "a good mother" 
by going home and being with her son and family. It was that internal 
conflict that drew her attention to all those "signs" on the highway and at 
the airport. It highlighted how vulnerability can lead to anxiety. On the 
flip side, she later explained how it can also lead to love and joy.
comments.author: Greg Hamilton

comments.text:
I really like what this woman says and I appreciate the work she has down 
both in her research and on herself to speak of shame, vulnerability and 
its link to happiness and fulfillment. People want to get to the latter 
without being open to the former and this never works--to the point where 
no one even wants to talk about it or have someone else talk about it. ﻿
comments.author: atelier27

comments.text:
One thing that is common of 90% of 'professional' people like her is they 
study what they lack:  They study what they don't have or can't control and 
don't understand.  I knew a married woman with a child who went back to 
university, 4 years of full time study to become a psychiatrist just so she 
could understand why she was an over-eating/obese fat person.  She ended up 
specializing in treating fat people with eating disorders.  She never 
managed to lose any weight or  control of her own over eating.   A fat 
overeating  psychiatrist treating fat overeating adolescents does not work. 
 She made a good living but she never helped any of her patients to control 
their overeating.  Her daughter became a fat obese tub of lard .  She make 
a good living as a professional but she's a total failure as a human being.

In short: before you try to heal anybody else;  heal yourself first.  Her 
story is a confession of what she does not have and wants but doesn't know 
how to achieve.   Her problem is she can'r be vulnerable:so she studies 
vulnerability.  She is the typical busy career woman control-freak neurotic 
which is the total opposite of what she should be.  trying to be a perfect 
mom, etc etc ad nausea  Buying into the non-existent terrorist bullshit 
with airport scanners now treating law abiding citizens as if they are 
criminals: Even worse: a boob tube  watcher!  Who watches these shows? I

comments.text:
I agree with your first point Adam - researchers do tend to study concepts 
they don't understand, or perhaps lack themselves. Brene has admitted as 
much in her earlier TED talks. She said vulnerability didn't come naturally 
to her, and she suffered a breakdown when her findings contradicted her 
beliefs. Her story was a confession that she was avoiding or protecting 
herself from vulnerability.

She shared this in a very public forum. By sharing this, she was BEING 
vulnerable. There she was, on stage, in front of hundreds of people, 
sharing her story, her life, her research, her vulnerabilities, admitting 
her breakdown - it doesn't get much more vulnerable and authentic than 
that. 

So, Adam, she was leading by example. She was being vulnerable while 
talking about vulnerability. She was sharing what she had learned, from 
both her research, and her life, so that others may also learn, appreciate 
and embrace their own vulnerability. 

Clearly from everything else you have written, you are experiencing your 
own vulnerability brought about by the various issues that you are clearly 
very passionate and concerned about. Clearly you are concerned with how 
vulnerable the environment is, and that is admirable.

I don't believe your personal attacks and critical assessments of others 
are warranted or helpful, however they do suggest to me that you possess a 
number of vulnerability shields. Perhaps your concerns would be better 
served by learning to lower your shields, sharing your concerns with other 
like-minded people, and directing your efforts towards helping the 
environment, rather than directing criticism and abuse towards people.
comments.author: Greg Hamilton

comments.text:
No, that is not what people need. That's a remedy as useful as numbing 
yourself... focusing your attention on someone else, telling others how 
they should live their lives, that's distraction from the interior. 
What people need it to look within and experience the pain and forgive 
themselves for feeling what they feel, thinking what they think, doing what 
they do. Learning how to forgive ourselves, then we can forgive others, 
including forgiving others for not appreciating what they have.
We have to stop punishing ourselves and others for not being what we want 
them to be. It's not our job to punish. Punishment is not love.﻿

comments.author: Michelle Bonneau

comments.text:
Very nice demonstration on the effectiveness of psychological or 
subconscious techniques to invoke a certain emotion in people. Open hands, 
a lone daisy, simple and aesthetically pleasing slides, the soft 
"soccer-mom" tone, the ho-hum story of her flight--but, how that relates to 
vulnerability, I couldn't tell you---I'm sure she made a point. I just 
don't know if it was about us being informed on vulnerability or about us 
being persuaded to be vulnerable.

Why don't we emphasize oration as its own field in our systemic educational 
institutions, any more?

Bravo!﻿
